    Fitting epicurves

    Tim Taylor

    fitting_epicurves.Rmd

    Example

    To illustrate the trend fitting functionality of incidence2plus we will use the simulated Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) outbreak data from the outbreaks package.

    Loading relevant packages and data

    library(outbreaks)
library(incidence2)
library(incidence2plus)
library(tidyr)

raw_dat <- ebola_sim_clean$linelist

    For this example we will restrict ourselves to the first 20 weeks of data:

    dat <- incidence(
    raw_dat, 
    date_index = date_of_onset,
    interval = 7
)[1:20, ]
dat
#> An incidence2 object: 20 x 2
#> [783 cases from days 2014-04-07 to 2014-08-18]
#> [interval: 7 days]
#> [cumulative: FALSE]
#> 
#>    bin_date   count
#>    <date>     <int>
#>  1 2014-04-07     1
#>  2 2014-04-14     1
#>  3 2014-04-21     5
#>  4 2014-04-28     4
#>  5 2014-05-05    12
#>  6 2014-05-12    17
#>  7 2014-05-19    15
#>  8 2014-05-26    19
#>  9 2014-06-02    23
#> 10 2014-06-09    21
#> 11 2014-06-16    30
#> 12 2014-06-23    22
#> 13 2014-06-30    34
#> 14 2014-07-07    38
#> 15 2014-07-14    61
#> 16 2014-07-21    59
#> 17 2014-07-28    80
#> 18 2014-08-04    86
#> 19 2014-08-11   116
#> 20 2014-08-18   139
plot(dat)

    Modeling incidence

    We can use fit_curve() to fit the data with either a poisson or negative binomial regression model. The output from this will be a nested object with class [incidence2_fit] which as methods available for both automatic plotting and the calculation of growth (decay) rates and doubling (halving) times.

    out <- fit_curve(dat, model = "poisson", alpha = 0.05)
out
#> # A tibble: 1 x 2
#>   model  estimates        
#>   <list> <list>           
#> 1 <glm>  <df[,5] [20 Ã— 5]>
out %>% unnest(estimates)
#> # A tibble: 20 x 6
#>    model  count bin_date   estimate lower_ci upper_ci
#>    <list> <int> <date>        <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>
#>  1 <glm>      1 2014-04-07     4.09     3.20     5.23
#>  2 <glm>      1 2014-04-14     4.92     3.91     6.19
#>  3 <glm>      5 2014-04-21     5.92     4.77     7.33
#>  4 <glm>      4 2014-04-28     7.11     5.82     8.68
#>  5 <glm>     12 2014-05-05     8.55     7.11    10.3 
#>  6 <glm>     17 2014-05-12    10.3      8.67    12.2 
#>  7 <glm>     15 2014-05-19    12.3     10.6     14.4 
#>  8 <glm>     19 2014-05-26    14.8     12.9     17.1 
#>  9 <glm>     23 2014-06-02    17.8     15.7     20.3 
#> 10 <glm>     21 2014-06-09    21.4     19.1     24.0 
#> 11 <glm>     30 2014-06-16    25.8     23.3     28.5 
#> 12 <glm>     22 2014-06-23    31.0     28.3     33.9 
#> 13 <glm>     34 2014-06-30    37.2     34.3     40.4 
#> 14 <glm>     38 2014-07-07    44.8     41.5     48.2 
#> 15 <glm>     61 2014-07-14    53.8     50.1     57.7 
#> 16 <glm>     59 2014-07-21    64.7     60.3     69.4 
#> 17 <glm>     80 2014-07-28    77.7     72.2     83.7 
#> 18 <glm>     86 2014-08-04    93.4     86.2    101.  
#> 19 <glm>    116 2014-08-11   112.     103.     123.  
#> 20 <glm>    139 2014-08-18   135.     122.     149.
out %>% plot()

    out %>% growth_rate()
#> # A tibble: 1 x 8
#>   groups      r r_lower r_upper growth_or_decay  time time_lower time_upper
#>   <chr>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>           <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>
#> 1 <NA>   0.0263  0.0240  0.0286 doubling         26.4       24.2       28.9

    fit_curve will also work on grouped incidence objects:

    grouped_dat <- incidence(
    raw_dat, 
    date_index = date_of_onset,
    interval = 7,
    groups = hospital
)[1:140, ]
grouped_dat
#> An incidence2 object: 140 x 3
#> [1535 cases from days 2014-04-07 to 2014-09-15]
#> [interval: 7 days]
#> [cumulative: FALSE]
#> 
#>    bin_date   hospital                                     count
#>    <date>     <fct>                                        <int>
#>  1 2014-04-07 Military Hospital                                1
#>  2 2014-04-07 Connaught Hospital                               0
#>  3 2014-04-07 other                                            0
#>  4 2014-04-07 <NA>                                             0
#>  5 2014-04-07 Princess Christian Maternity Hospital (PCMH)     0
#>  6 2014-04-07 Rokupa Hospital                                  0
#>  7 2014-04-14 Military Hospital                                0
#>  8 2014-04-14 Connaught Hospital                               1
#>  9 2014-04-14 other                                            0
#> 10 2014-04-14 <NA>                                             0
#> # â€¦ with 130 more rows

out <- fit_curve(grouped_dat, model = "poisson", alpha = 0.05)
out
#> # A tibble: 6 x 7
#>   hospital model estimates fitting_warning fitting_error prediction_warnâ€¦
#>   <fct>    <lis> <list>    <list>          <list>        <list>          
#> 1 Connaugâ€¦ <glm> <df[,5] â€¦ <NULL>          <NULL>        <NULL>          
#> 2 Militarâ€¦ <glm> <df[,5] â€¦ <NULL>          <NULL>        <NULL>          
#> 3 other    <glm> <df[,5] â€¦ <NULL>          <NULL>        <NULL>          
#> 4 Princesâ€¦ <glm> <df[,5] â€¦ <NULL>          <NULL>        <NULL>          
#> 5 Rokupa â€¦ <glm> <df[,5] â€¦ <NULL>          <NULL>        <NULL>          
#> 6 <NA>     <glm> <df[,5] â€¦ <NULL>          <NULL>        <NULL>          
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: prediction_error <list>
out %>% plot()

    out %>% growth_rate()
#> Note: incidence2_fit class dropped in returned object
#> # A tibble: 6 x 8
#>   hospital         r r_lower r_upper growth_or_decay  time time_lower time_upper
#>   <fct>        <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>           <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>
#> 1 Connaught â€¦ 0.0287  0.0260  0.0315 doubling         24.2       22.0       26.7
#> 2 Military Hâ€¦ 0.0260  0.0225  0.0298 doubling         26.6       23.3       30.8
#> 3 other       0.0257  0.0217  0.0299 doubling         27.0       23.2       31.9
#> 4 Princess Câ€¦ 0.0253  0.0196  0.0315 doubling         27.4       22.0       35.3
#> 5 Rokupa Hosâ€¦ 0.0287  0.0225  0.0355 doubling         24.2       19.5       30.8
#> 6 <NA>        0.0258  0.0227  0.0291 doubling         26.8       23.8       30.5

    Rolling average

    We can add a rolling average, across current and previous intervals, to an incidence2 object with the add_rolling_average() function:

    ra <- 
  grouped_dat %>% 
  add_rolling_average(before = 2) # group observations with the 2 prior
ra
#> # A tibble: 6 x 2
#>   hospital                                     rolling_average  
#>   <fct>                                        <list>           
#> 1 Connaught Hospital                           <tibble [24 Ã— 3]>
#> 2 Military Hospital                            <tibble [24 Ã— 3]>
#> 3 other                                        <tibble [23 Ã— 3]>
#> 4 Princess Christian Maternity Hospital (PCMH) <tibble [23 Ã— 3]>
#> 5 Rokupa Hospital                              <tibble [23 Ã— 3]>
#> 6 <NA>                                         <tibble [23 Ã— 3]>
ra %>% unnest(rolling_average)
#> # A tibble: 140 x 4
#>    hospital           bin_date   count rolling_average
#>    <fct>              <date>     <int>           <dbl>
#>  1 Connaught Hospital 2014-04-07     0          NA    
#>  2 Connaught Hospital 2014-04-14     1          NA    
#>  3 Connaught Hospital 2014-04-21     0           0.333
#>  4 Connaught Hospital 2014-04-28     1           0.667
#>  5 Connaught Hospital 2014-05-05     3           1.33 
#>  6 Connaught Hospital 2014-05-12     2           2.00 
#>  7 Connaught Hospital 2014-05-19     5           3.33 
#>  8 Connaught Hospital 2014-05-26     4           3.67 
#>  9 Connaught Hospital 2014-06-02     6           5    
#> 10 Connaught Hospital 2014-06-09     6           5.33 
#> # â€¦ with 130 more rows

plot(ra, color = "white")
#> Warning: Removed 12 rows containing missing values (position_stack).

#> Warning: Removed 12 rows containing missing values (position_stack).
